messages.subject: confusing post
messages.msgSnippet: If you were quoting me, it d probably sound like, I don t believe the Bible is literally true but I don t want to admit it to myself yet. ;) Sheila Well, if
messages.messageBody:
"If you were quoting me, it'd probably sound like, "I don't believe
the Bible is literally true but I don't want to admit it to myself
yet. ;)

Sheila"

Well, if it makes you feel any better, the world is a lot less scary and better from this side!:) I understand the fear associated with letting go of lifelong belief systems, but once you start questioning things it's so durn hard to stop eh? Pretty cool.
I am so much more happy and fulfilled since I let go of religion and embraced my spirituality. Not living from a place of fear has allowed me to love more fully, live more joyfully and truly be a life long learner.
There is so much to see when you get out from behind a narrow view...so much truth and beauty and real life stuff. Don't be afraid to explore it, freedom is a wonderful thing.

Ren

messages.subject: Re: confusing post
messages.msgSnippet: ... did. ... religions ... really unique and ... and not a ... aimed at Sheila. Sounded like I thought I was quoting Sheila....too many thoughts tumbling
messages.messageBody:
--- In UnschoolingDiscussion@yahoogroups.com, Ren <starsuncloud@n...>
wrote:
>
> "I don't believe the Bible is literally true, though at one time I
did.
> Reading more about the history of the Bible and then reading other
religions'
> sacred texts cured me of the idea that the Bible was something
really unique and
>
> special. It's a collection of things of varying relative values,
and not a
> monolithic item created in a moment by a clear-eyed entity. "
>
> I was quoting this from Sandra.
> My last post was a bit confusing, I realized, since some of it was
aimed at Sheila. Sounded like I thought I was quoting Sheila....too
many thoughts tumbling around in my little 'ol brain.:)
>
> Ren

If you were quoting me, it'd probably sound like, "I don't believe
the Bible is literally true but I don't want to admit it to myself
yet. ;)

Sheila

messages.subject: confusing post
messages.msgSnippet: I don t believe the Bible is literally true, though at one time I did. Reading more about the history of the Bible and then reading other religions sacred
messages.messageBody:
"I don't believe the Bible is literally true, though at one time I did.
Reading more about the history of the Bible and then reading other religions'
sacred texts cured me of the idea that the Bible was something really unique and

special. It's a collection of things of varying relative values, and not a
monolithic item created in a moment by a clear-eyed entity. "

I was quoting this from Sandra.
My last post was a bit confusing, I realized, since some of it was aimed at Sheila. Sounded like I thought I was quoting Sheila....too many thoughts tumbling around in my little 'ol brain.:)

Ren
